Definition: A reflex involving the opening of the mouth, deep inhalation, and stretching of the eardrums, often associated with tiredness or boredom. Its neural mechanisms involve the hypothalamus and brain stem.

An empirical relationship between arousal and performance, suggesting that performance increases with physiological or mental arousal, but only up to a point. When arousal becomes too high, performance decreases.
A genetic condition where small segments of the Y chromosome are missing, often associated with male infertility and sometimes linked to neurodevelopmental disorders.
An alkaloid derived from the bark of the yohimbe tree, used as an alpha-2 adrenergic receptor antagonist. In neuroscience research, it is used to study anxiety and noradrenergic systems.
A theory of color vision proposing that the eye has three types of photoreceptors (cones) sensitive to red, green, and blue light. Also known as trichromatic theory.
